subject: Home & DIY
title: Vinyl Siding Is Basically PVC
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Vinyl Siding Is Basically PVC.

hook.text: Vinyl siding covers 32% of US homes. It's PVCâ€”same plastic as drain pipesâ€”stamped into wood shapes and hung on walls.

buildup.text: PVC (polyvinyl chloride) is the world's third-most-made plastic. Rigid PVC is strong, cheap, and never needs painting.

discovery.text: Vinyl siding hangs on nails through slotted holes, letting it expand and contract with temperatureâ€”never screwed tight.

twist.text: Vinyl melts at just 100Â°C, well below fire temps. A grill too close to a vinyl wall melts a hole in minutes.

climax.text: PVC production releases dioxins and disposal is toxic. Despite being recyclable in theory, under 1% is ever recycled.

punchline.text: Cheap, durable, and almost never recycled.

quiz.question: Why does vinyl siding hang on slotted nail holes instead of being screwed tight?
options: To allow the panels to expand and contract with temperature changes
To make replacement easier when panels crack
To create an air gap for ventilation behind the siding
